tags: I'm telling you these two are hot for one another and I
will go to my grave with this headcanon
summary: So I'm not really a 'shipper'.  It's an extremely rare case when I become attached in any way, let alone super attached, to two...
body:
So I’m not really a ‘shipper’.  It’s an extremely rare case when I become attached in any way, let alone super attached, to two written characters being together.  I’m not sure what that says about me, but there it is. It probably comes from the same issue of my lack of emotion  when writing, for the most part.   My life rules on empathy but my writing style is very detached and logical.


HOWEVER, reading the last two runs of Jessica Jones (fell off comics after qutting a reviewing job in 2016), I’ve come to the realization that I HARDCORE ship Carol Danvers and Jessica Jones together and I just never mentally put the words too it before. 


Part of it prolly comes from how much of a shit-show Cage is with her.  It’s not that I hate it or even dislike it, as I sometimes think it works, when Luke is allowed to show some form of weakness as a human being and not be the angry and overprotective dickhead that most (BENDIS) writes him as.  But it’s always been an addition to HIS character rather than hers, and that’s a hard thing to accept when it happened in HER first run as a victim of the atypical Marvel 'let’s give this woman a baby to make her “more interesting” trope that they so love.


It’s a typical Bendis thing to do and I wouldn’t realize that until he was miserably writing the X-Men, BUT ANYWAY


Also with Captain Marvel being CAPTAIN MARVEL now and therefor way more interesting than Marvel often let her be before the change (even with the nonsense in Civil War II), I’ve just come to the sudden, smack-in-the-face realization that those two grown women are each others unknowing soulmates.

Also the more recent runs get SUPER LESS ‘I’m hooking you up with a friend to get you laid cuz I’m secrectly in love with you’ and SUPER MORE ‘I WOULD DIE FOR YOU YOU DUMB BISCH’ 

Like the 2016 run involves her literally lying to Luke Cage, kidnapping her kid and bringing her to her asshole of a Mother JUST SO SHE COULD GO UNDERCOVER FOR CAROL.  SHE SPENT SIX MONTHS IN PRISON AND RUINED HER LIFE FOR CAROL!  

Also I’m sure the normal response to this would be, ‘She was doing the right thing, Luke would undertand’ and yeah you’re kind right except JESSICA JONES ISN’T REALLY KNOWN FOR CARING ABOUT THE ACTUAL SUPERHEROY STUFF, SHE HATES IT, SOOOOOO.  All I’m saying is that it might be driven by an unsaid love for her ‘best friend’,

Also there’s that time a bit later where Carol is told to stay away from Purple Man, so she hired KRAVEN THE HUNTER as a hit man to kill him and when that goes wrong she goes to beat the shit out of him and gets brought under his control.  

Also all I’m saying is that Purple Man once showed her ‘her worst fear’, and all I’ma say is that it’s not a super straight fear.  

So tldr;  Carol Danvers and Jessica Jones are soulmates and also a SUPER HEALTHY PAIRING FOR ONE ANOTHER and I can’t believe it took me nearly fifteen years to realize it.

blog.name: kanadabiscuits
blog.title: There is a crack in everything... That's how the light gets in
blog.description:
Sam. Forty-something Canadian. Here for the fic, the friendships, and the abject silliness you can only find when like minds meet over shared obsessions. 
My blog is my happy place, bring your joy and your flails and your thinky thoughts, but check your wank at the door. I have no room in my life or on my blog for hate. Laugh hard, run fast,  be kind.

summary:
ckerouac replied to your post:
                    Sooooo…. we watched the extended Aquaman trailer...                
    omg...
body:
ckerouac replied to your post: Sooooo…. we watched the extended Aquaman trailer…
omg ‘booyah syndrome’ is exactly the phrase i’ve been looking for to describe these types of movies. you weren’t the only who was underwhelmed by it. my immediate reaction was… meh. i’ve seen this before. but the comments on youtube, oh the comments… so many ‘this is SO MUCH BETTER than captain marvel, this is what a superhero movie is supposed to be’ and i’m like ’…just say you don’t want icky women in your movies, just admit it’

…just say you don’t want icky women in your movies, just admit it’

Exactly. And he didn’t smile much either…

Plus, the Captain Marvel trailer wasn’t a trailer, it was a teaser, just meant to give a taste and no more, and even then it gave me chills of YES and anticipation when the triptych of Carols pulled themselves up from the ground, rising strong and resolute. That told me everything I needed to know about the heart of this movie. It is about a woman who learns how to fall and fail and get back up again, stronger for the failure, wiser and more powerful.

Aquaman gave me no heart. It is a story we have seen before, and seen done very well. Give me something new dammit. Earn your stupid “Booyah”s…

summary: The screams have faded to distant, wracking sobs. Valkyrie’s elbows slip out slowly from beneath her until she lays on her back,...
body:
The screams have faded to distant, wracking sobs. Valkyrie’s elbows slip out slowly from beneath her until she lays on her back, gazing blankly at the lightless sky. Two empty bottles lay at her hip. Her heart thuds dully.

She hasn’t felt so tired in a long, long time.

When she closes her eyes, the people on Midgard fade to dust and catch on the unforgiving breeze, hearts and lungs mingling, indistinguishable. She feels calm. She waits for the air to claim her, a painless swipe of cloth against slate.

Except it doesn’t. Except she doesn’t return to her fallen friends (and, in one case, maybe more)—she opens her eyes and the wind seeps into her mouth and she is still very much alive.

So she helps. Not that there’s much anybody can do. She tugs flailing helicopters from the paths of half-filled buildings and stands listlessly before swerving cars. When the terror dies down, she leaves the sobbing cities behind.

She wonders if Thor or Loki are dust on the wind.

These thoughts startle her awake. Valkyrie becomes uncomfortably aware of the ashes of billions in Earth’s atmosphere. Perhaps that’s why she can’t see starlight.

A hand, soft and delicate, touches her shoulder.

“Fuck,” says Valkyrie. But she’s not afraid of villains anymore.

“It’s okay,” says the voice. “I’m here to help.”

The woman takes a seat beside her. Valkyrie doesn’t ask how she made it onto the roof of a long-abandoned Blockbuster Video store. She doesn’t even look.

“I don’t think there’s particularly much to be done,” she responds dryly, adjusting her position to tuck her chin over her knees.

Silence settles around them. It is complete, and chilling. No chirping of birds or crickets. The streets are devoid of cars.

“There is hope.”

The determined tinge to the woman’s voice makes Valkyrie look up in surprise.

The woman has short blonde hair that seems to move like a living entity, swaying ever so softly despite the absence of a breeze, and if Valkyrie’s eyes do not deceive her, it appears to be emitting it’s own kindling glow. She wears a suit of red and blue and gold.

Valkyrie crosses her legs and her bare thigh brushes the burning hot skin of the woman.

“You’re a god?” asks Valkyrie.

“I am a Captain,” the woman smiles. “You can call me Carol.”

“I’m”—Valkyrie pauses, extensively, trying to calculate whether her name would be as painful on anyone else’s than her dead lover’s tongue; but then she says—“Brunnhilde.”

“Brunnhilde,” says Carol, and it’s like a part of her has reawakened, that another godlike woman is hovering at her shoulder. “How about we save the universe?”

Valkyrie smiles. She takes Carol’s open hand and the warmth fills her bones and heart.

“I guess I’ve got nothing better to do.”

The screams have faded to distant, wracking sobs. Valkyrie’s elbows slip out slowly from beneath her until she lays on her back, gazing blankly at the lightless sky. Two empty bottles lay at her hip. Her heart thuds dully.

She hasn’t felt so tired in a long, long time.

When she closes her eyes, the people on Midgard fade to dust and catch on the unforgiving breeze, hearts and lungs mingling, indistinguishable. She feels calm. She waits for the air to claim her, a painless swipe of cloth against slate.

Except it doesn’t. Except she doesn’t return to her fallen friends (and, in one case, maybe more)—she opens her eyes and the wind seeps into her mouth and she is still very much alive.

So she helps. Not that there’s much anybody can do. She tugs flailing helicopters from the paths of half-filled buildings and stands listlessly before swerving cars. When the terror dies down, she leaves the sobbing cities behind.

She wonders if Thor or Loki are dust on the wind.

These thoughts startle her awake. Valkyrie becomes uncomfortably aware of the ashes of billions in Earth’s atmosphere. Perhaps that’s why she can’t see starlight.

A hand, soft and delicate, touches her shoulder.

“Fuck,” says Valkyrie. But she’s not afraid of villains anymore.

“It’s okay,” says the voice. “I’m here to help.”

The woman takes a seat beside her. Valkyrie doesn’t ask how she made it onto the roof of a long-abandoned Blockbuster Video store. She doesn’t even look.

“I don’t think there’s particularly much to be done,” she responds dryly, adjusting her position to tuck her chin over her knees.

Silence settles around them. It is complete, and chilling. No chirping of birds or crickets. The streets are devoid of cars.

“There is hope.”

The determined tinge to the woman’s voice makes Valkyrie look up in surprise.

The woman has short blonde hair that seems to move like a living entity, swaying ever so softly despite the absence of a breeze, and if Valkyrie’s eyes do not deceive her, it appears to be emitting it’s own kindling glow. She wears a suit of red and blue and gold.

Valkyrie crosses her legs and her bare thigh brushes the burning hot skin of the woman.

“You’re a god?” asks Valkyrie.

“I am a Captain,” the woman smiles. “You can call me Carol.”

“I’m”—Valkyrie pauses, extensively, trying to calculate whether her name would be as painful on anyone else’s than her dead lover’s tongue; but then she says—“Brunnhilde.”

“Brunnhilde,” says Carol, and it’s like a part of her has reawakened, that another godlike woman is hovering at her shoulder. “How about we save the universe?”

Valkyrie smiles. She takes Carol’s open hand and the warmth fills her bones and heart.

“I guess I’ve got nothing better to do.”
trail.content:
The screams have faded to distant, wracking sobs. Valkyrie’s elbows slip out slowly from beneath her until she lays on her back, gazing blankly at the lightless sky. Two empty bottles lay at her hip. Her heart thuds dully.

She hasn’t felt so tired in a long, long time.

When she closes her eyes, the people on Midgard fade to dust and catch on the unforgiving breeze, hearts and lungs mingling, indistinguishable. She feels calm. She waits for the air to claim her, a painless swipe of cloth against slate.

Except it doesn’t. Except she doesn’t return to her fallen friends (and, in one case, maybe more)—she opens her eyes and the wind seeps into her mouth and she is still very much alive.

So she helps. Not that there’s much anybody can do. She tugs flailing helicopters from the paths of half-filled buildings and stands listlessly before swerving cars. When the terror dies down, she leaves the sobbing cities behind.

She wonders if Thor or Loki are dust on the wind.

These thoughts startle her awake. Valkyrie becomes uncomfortably aware of the ashes of billions in Earth’s atmosphere. Perhaps that’s why she can’t see starlight.

A hand, soft and delicate, touches her shoulder.

“Fuck,” says Valkyrie. But she’s not afraid of villains anymore.

“It’s okay,” says the voice. “I’m here to help.”

The woman takes a seat beside her. Valkyrie doesn’t ask how she made it onto the roof of a long-abandoned Blockbuster Video store. She doesn’t even look.

“I don’t think there’s particularly much to be done,” she responds dryly, adjusting her position to tuck her chin over her knees.

Silence settles around them. It is complete, and chilling. No chirping of birds or crickets. The streets are devoid of cars.

“There is hope.”

The determined tinge to the woman’s voice makes Valkyrie look up in surprise.

The woman has short blonde hair that seems to move like a living entity, swaying ever so softly despite the absence of a breeze, and if Valkyrie’s eyes do not deceive her, it appears to be emitting it’s own kindling glow. She wears a suit of red and blue and gold.

Valkyrie crosses her legs and her bare thigh brushes the burning hot skin of the woman.

“You’re a god?” asks Valkyrie.

“I am a Captain,” the woman smiles. “You can call me Carol.”

“I’m”—Valkyrie pauses, extensively, trying to calculate whether her name would be as painful on anyone else’s than her dead lover’s tongue; but then she says—“Brunnhilde.”

“Brunnhilde,” says Carol, and it’s like a part of her has reawakened, that another godlike woman is hovering at her shoulder. “How about we save the universe?”

Valkyrie smiles. She takes Carol’s open hand and the warmth fills her bones and heart.

“I guess I’ve got nothing better to do.”

tags: i think thats her last name dont @ me
summary:
Hey y’all wanna know something that makes Chris Evans’ tweet sadder?
Our Captain is leaving. He’s been with us for years, and...
body:
Hey y’all wanna know something that makes Chris Evans’ tweet sadder?

Our Captain is leaving. He’s been with us for years, and we’ve grown to love him and experience his journey with him. There’s been highs and lows and people can say what they want, it won’t change that he’s an amazing character.

And now another Captain is rising to the challenge. We’ll experience her development, grow with her, laugh with her, maybe even cry with her. Captain Marvel, welcome to the family.

summary: i was telling my dad the backstory to captain marvel bc he watched the trailer and liked it a lot, when my brother walked in and...
body: i was telling my dad the backstory to captain marvel bc he watched the trailer and liked it a lot, when my brother walked in and goes “oH, thAT, she wasn’t the FIRST captain marvel….” as if that makes her any less a captain marvel??? like fuck off??? do u know any comics my bro everyone knows she ain’t the first captain marvel, that means jack shit.
